contentrichtext.text: {{Korean name|[[Yu (Korean name)|Yu]]}} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul=유성원 |hanja=柳誠源 |rr=Yu Seong(-)won |mr=Ryu Sŏngwŏn |hangulja=태초 |hanjaja=太初 |rrja=Taecho |mrja=T'aech'o |hangulho=낭간 |hanjaho=琅玕 |rrho=Nanggan |mrho=Nanggan }} '''Yu Seong-won''' (also '''Ryu Seong-won''') (died 1456) was a scholar-official of the early [[Joseon Dynasty]], who is remembered as one of the [[six murdered ministers]]. He was born to a [[yangban]] family of the [[Munhwa Ryu]] lineage, but his date of birth is not known. Yu passed the lower examination 1444 and the higher examination in 1447. He was shortly thereafter appointed to the [[Hall of Worthies]] by [[Sejong the Great of Joseon|Sejong]]. Yu was among the compilers of the first edition of the [[Classified Collection of Medical Prescriptions]] (''yu bang yu chwi'', 醫方類聚), together with other members of the Hall of Worthies.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://medhist.kams.or.kr/index.asp?body=1999187a|title=Authors of the Classified Collection of Medical Prescriptions|work=Korean Journal of Medical History 8(2)|author=Shin, Soon Shik|accessdate=2006-04-09|year=1999}}</ref> In 1455, [[Sejo of Joseon|Sejo]] overthrew the reigning king [[Danjong of Joseon|Danjong]]. Yu joined with other high officials in a conspiracy to restore Danjong to the throne. This was discovered by the king shortly before it was to happen, and Yu committed suicide. Yu's tomb lies today in [[Sayuksin Park]] in [[Noryangjin-dong]], [[Dongjak-gu]], [[Seoul]].
